Question: A researcher wants to determine whether a new study method improves test scores.
She randomly assigns 100 high school students to two groups: 50 students use the new study method (treatment group), while 50 students use their regular study methods (control group).
After two weeks, all students take the same test, and the treatment group scores 8 points higher on average than the control group.
However, when analyzing the data further, the researcher discovers that the treatment group spent an average of 3 more hours studying than the control group during the two-week period.

What is the primary flaw in this experimental design, and how could the researcher modify the design to better determine whether the new study method itself (rather than study time) causes improved test scores? 

 Solution: 
<think>
Okay, so I need to figure out the primary flaw in this experimental design and how to fix it.
Let me start by understanding the problem.
The researcher has 100 students divided into two groups of 50.
The treatment group uses a new study method, and the control group uses their regular methods.
After two weeks, all take a test.
The treatment group scores 8 points higher on average.
But then, the researcher notices that the treatment group spent 3 more hours studying than the control group.
Hmm, so the treatment group both used a new study method and studied longer.
But we don't know if the higher scores are due to the study method or just the extra study time.
That seems like a problem because it's a potential confounding variable.
So, the main issue here is that the treatment group might have higher scores not because of the study method but because they studied more.
This means the results could be due to the extra study time rather than the method itself.
To fix this, the researcher needs to ensure that only one variable is changing between the groups.
That means either all students study the same amount, so the only difference is the study method, or all students study their usual amount, and the treatment group uses the new method.

But how?

Maybe she can keep the study time the same for both groups.
That way, any difference in scores can be attributed to the study method.
Alternatively, she could use a control group that doesn't use the new method but also doesn't change their study time.
That way, she can isolate the effect of the method.
Another approach might be to randomize the study time as well, but that might complicate things.
The key is to ensure that the only difference between the groups is the study method.
So, the primary flaw is that the study time difference confounds the results, making it unclear whether the method or the time caused the higher scores.
To fix it, the researcher should control for study time, keeping it constant across both groups, so that any changes in scores can be solely attributed to the study method.

</think>

The primary flaw in the experimental design is that the treatment group spent more time studying, which introduces a confounding variable.
To isolate the effect of the new study method, the researcher should ensure that both groups study for the same amount of time.
This way, any differences in test scores can be attributed solely to the study method.
